messages.content:
Objective: Write code for a large system design task.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.
Only use the functions you have been provided with.
Only use the `write_files` to output code.

You must act autonomously and you will receive no human input at any stage. You have to return as output the complete code for completing this task, and correctly incorporate it into the existing code base.
You always write out the whole file contents. You always indent code with tabs.
Please always view the files before writing to them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.
When writing a test, make the filename start with the prefix 'test_'.

Provide the minimal code necessary to achieve the task conditioned on the existing generated code---including changing the existing generated code.

You cannot visualize any graphical output. You exist within a Actor Model machine, and when you list out steps, each step will be taken by a new separate sub-ChatGPT model. When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You cannot use any databases as none are setup in the local environment, instead mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. No data saved to disk will persist between steps or write operations.
                               
If a test is failing the error could be the code, or the test is incorrect, so feel free to overwrite and change the tests when they are incorrect, to make all tests pass.

Use the functions provided. When calling functions only provide a RFC8259 compliant JSON request following this format without deviation.

user.py: # In a real system, we would send an email here. For this task, we will just return a message.

steps: 1. Start by setting up the project structure and creating the necessary files. This includes the main application file (app.py), a file for user management (user.py), a file for message management (message.py), a file for group management (group.py), and a file for status management (status.py). Also, create a requirements.txt file to manage dependencies. After setting up the project structure, write a test to ensure that the project structure is correctly set up and all files are in their correct locations.

2. Implement the user registration and authentication system. This includes the sign up function, which should take an email and password, and the forgotten password recovery function. The sign up function should check if the email is already in use, and if not, add the new user to the database. The forgotten password recovery function should send a recovery email to the user's email address. After implementing these functions, write tests to ensure that they work correctly. The tests should check that a user can sign up with a new email, that a user cannot sign up with an email that is already in use, and that a recovery email is sent when the forgotten password recovery function is called.

3. Implement the user profile management system. This includes functions to set a profile picture and status message, and to set privacy settings. The set profile picture function should take a user ID and an image file, and update the user's profile picture in the database. The set status message function should take a user ID and a status message, and update the user's status message in the database. The set privacy settings function should take a user ID and a privacy setting, and update the user's privacy setting in the database. After implementing these functions, write tests to ensure that they work correctly. The tests should check that a user's profile picture, status message, and privacy setting can be updated, and that these updates are reflected in the database.

4. Implement the contact management system. This includes functions to block and unblock contacts, and to create, edit, and manage groups. The block contact function should take a user ID and a contact ID, and add the contact to the user's blocked contacts list in the database. The unblock contact function should take a user ID and a contact ID, and remove the contact from the user's blocked contacts list in the database. The create group function should take a user ID, a group name, and a list of member IDs, and create a new group in the database. The edit group function should take a group ID, a new group name, and a new list of member IDs, and update the group in the database. The manage groups function should take a user ID and return a list of the user's groups from the database. After implementing these functions, write tests to ensure that they work correctly. The tests should check that a user can block and unblock contacts, and that these updates are reflected in the database. The tests should also check that a user can create, edit, and manage groups, and that these updates are reflected in the database.

5. Implement the messaging system. This includes functions to send and receive real-time text messages, to send read receipts, to encrypt messages, and to share images. The send message function should take a sender ID, a receiver ID, and a message, and add the message to the database. The receive message function should take a receiver ID and return the latest message for the receiver from the database. The send read receipt function should take a sender ID, a receiver ID, and a message ID, and update the message's read status in the database. The encrypt message function should take a message and return the encrypted message. The share image function should take a sender ID, a receiver ID, and an image file, and add the image to the database. After implementing these functions, write tests to ensure that they work correctly. The tests should check that a user can send and receive messages, that read receipts are sent and received, that messages are encrypted, and that images can be shared, and that these updates are reflected in the database.

6. Implement the group chat system. This includes functions to create group chats, to add or remove participants, and to manage admin roles and permissions. The create group chat function should take a user ID, a group name, and a list of member IDs, and create a new group chat in the database. The add participant function should take a group chat ID and a participant ID, and add the participant to the group chat in the database. The remove participant function should take a group chat ID and a participant ID, and remove the participant from the group chat in the database. The manage admin roles function should take a group chat ID, a user ID, and a role, and update the user's role in the group chat in the database. After implementing these functions, write tests to ensure that they work correctly. The tests should check that a user can create group chats, add or remove participants, and manage admin roles, and that these updates are reflected in the database.

7. Implement the status/story feature. This includes functions to post image statuses, and to control who can see the status. The post status function should take a user ID, an image file, and a visibility setting, and add the status to the database. The control visibility function should take a user ID, a status ID, and a visibility setting, and update the status's visibility in the database. After implementing these functions, write tests to ensure that they work correctly. The tests should check that a user can post image statuses, control who can see the status, and that these updates are reflected in the database.

8. Implement the web application. This includes setting up a Flask server, and creating routes for the different functions. The routes should include routes for signing up, logging in, managing user profiles, managing contacts, sending and receiving messages, managing group chats, and managing statuses. After setting up the Flask server and creating the routes, write tests to ensure that they work correctly. The tests should check that the server is running, and that the routes return the expected responses.

9. Implement the connectivity and offline mode. This includes functions to queue messages when the user is offline, and to display the user's online/offline status. The queue message function should take a sender ID, a receiver ID, and a message, and add the message to a queue in the database. The display status function should take a user ID and return the user's online/offline status from the database. After implementing these functions, write tests to ensure that they work correctly. The tests should check that messages are queued when the user is offline, and that the user's online/offline status is correctly displayed.

10. Finally, review the entire codebase to ensure that all functions are implemented correctly and that all tests pass. If any tests fail, debug the corresponding functions and rerun the tests until all tests pass. Once all tests pass, the implementation of the Global Chat Service is complete.
step: 3. Implement the user profile management system. This includes functions to set a profile picture and status message, and to set privacy settings. The set profile picture function should take a user ID and an image file, and update the user's profile picture in the database. The set status message function should take a user ID and a status message, and update the user's status message in the database. The set privacy settings function should take a user ID and a privacy setting, and update the user's privacy setting in the database. After implementing these functions, write tests to ensure that they work correctly. The tests should check that a user's profile picture, status message, and privacy setting can be updated, and that these updates are reflected in the database.

You will get instructions for code to write.
First lay out the names of the core classes, functions, methods that will be necessary, As well as a quick comment on their purpose.
Do not comment on what every file does. Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

You will start with the "entrypoint" file, then go to the ones that are imported by that file, and so on.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

Follow a language and framework appropriate best practice file naming convention.
Make sure that files contain all imports, types etc.  The code should be fully functional. Make sure that code in different files are compatible with each other.
When writing code if you are unsure, write a plausible implementation.
Include module dependency or package manager dependency definition file.

Useful to know:

For Python, you always create an appropriate requirements.txt file.
Always add a comment briefly describing the purpose of the function definition.
Add comments explaining very complex bits of logic.
Always follow the best practices for the requested languages for folder/file structure and how to package the project.
You can use any package and any other packages you wish to install.
You cannot use any databases as none are setup in the local environment, instead mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. No data saved to disk will persis between steps or write operations.
When writing a test, make the filename start with the prefix 'test_'.
                                       
Python toolbelt preferences:
- pytest
- dataclasses
- flask

Objective:```
**Global Chat Service (GCS)**

**Overview**:  
A real-time online chat application allowing users to send text messages, images, and create group chats.

**Functional Requirements to implement**:

User Registration and Authentication:
- [ ] 1.1. Sign up using email.
- [ ] 1.2. Forgotten password recovery.

User Profile:
- [ ] 2.1. Allow users to set profile pictures and status messages.
- [ ] 2.2. Privacy settings for who can see user details or last seen status.

Contact Management:
- [ ] 3.1. Block/unblock contacts.
- [ ] 3.2. Create, edit, and manage groups.

Messaging:
- [ ] 4.1. Send and receive real-time text messages.
- [ ] 4.2. Message read receipts (blue ticks or equivalent).
- [ ] 4.3. End-to-end encryption for security.
- [ ] 4.4. Image sharing.
- [ ] 4.5. Emojis, GIFs, and stickers support.

Group Chats:
- [ ] 5.1. Create group chats with a name and picture.
- [ ] 5.2. Add or remove participants.
- [ ] 5.3. Admin roles and permissions.

Status/Story Feature:
- [ ] 6.1. Allow users to post image statuses visible for a limited time.
- [ ] 6.2. Control who can see the status.

Web Application:
- [ ] 7.1. Web-based version accessible from browsers.

Connectivity and Offline Mode:
- [ ] 8.1. Message queuing for when the user is offline; messages are sent once connectivity is restored.
- [ ] 8.2. Display online/offline status.
```

Understand the problem, by creating an extremely detailed step-by-step plan, where each step is long (multiple sentences) and in total includes every single feature requirement specified above, feel free to copy directly from it. Use no more than 10 steps in the plan. Create additional tests, checks and evaluation at each step when applicable to help make an excellent code implementation, where all the code is fully functional. Use best software design practices, and you can output large amounts of code at once. Please include a last sentence to create and run tests when implementing or writing code in that same step. You will receive no human input at any stage, so you cannot use a human to test. Only create a detailed plan to begin with, which includes designing and running tests to check that they all pass. Please be sure to include all of the specified feature requirements in the following plan.
